column4: so if anyone wanted to impersonate a repo, it couldn't impersonate the Release file, and if it was going to impersonate packages, it would, at least, have to maintain the checksum. Which I imagine is possible although tricky
yeah I need to go to bed as well
If your concern is safety.. it has been well thought out
Not even close to an informed opinion
Let me see f I can find the article that explains it better
http://librenix.com/?inode=21  is another good one.
I suggest that if you wish to discuss it you jump over to #ubuntu-offtopic.. this is the support room
look at this   http://xwinman.org/
Please /join #ubuntu-offtopic for discussions..
why?
this is support, it is not for polls or discussions...
I am getting support. I am discovering information about Hardy.
Not the same thing
http://packages.ubuntu.com/hardy/
thank you my good fellow.
I think that website lists all ubuntu-compatible software, as it lists items that are not on my ubuntu system.
so the question is this: what is considered ESSENTIAL ubuntu, who makes that decision, and where is the list?
they may be in uyniverse or multivers or backports or proposed etc..  but all are in our repos
they may be in the repos, and that tells me that they can run on ubuntu. However, when I install ubuntu, I don't get those packages.
So who makes the ubuntu installation, and what goes on it?
this is on-topic]
